subject: Add internationalization documentation
commitMessage:
Add internationalization documentation

- Explains how internationalization makes the OpenBMC Web UI
  multilingual
- Explains the use of vue-i18n

Signed-off-by: Sandeepa Singh <sandeepa.singh@ibm.com>
Change-Id: Ica273814a857f37502b9bb71800de7660d4fa49b

comments.message:
Patch Set 3:

(8 comments)

For the formatting changes related to code examples, here is a screen capture of the differences it makes when we use the proper alignment and code example type. Thank you for your efforts!

https://imgur.com/a/dyydeYk
Patch Set 6: Commit message was updated.
Patch Set 7: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 56ada53a80c2183f3055661aa8e0f707e4c6669d by Derick Montague
2 spaces at the end of sentance.

Maybe point out something like "This project implements internationalization, and separates out the ..."

Just to point out that internationalization is a whole field, this is one implementation of it.
Yes, this is a better way of writing ,also I'll be replacing 'this project' with 'the OpenBMC Web UI'

I am not sure that has the same value here since this is a web implementation and the UI itself has a container that will handle this. I suspect you expect some not to use the GUI documentation and only look here?

> I am not sure that has the same value here since this is a web implementation and the UI itself has a container that will handle this. I suspect you expect some not to use the GUI documentation and only look here?

I would expect all openbmc documentation in markdown within openbmc to be held to the same standard, regardless of what repo it's in.  Not everyone is using the github UI, and when we do docs reviews like this, it will need to be readable in text form, until someone figures out a better way to do markdown diffs in gerrit.

> Ack

We will need to update every document to support this. It's a reasonable request for allowing readability in GitHub. We should update this page and over time update the rest. I can add Help Wanted stories in the repo for this.

Will breaking at 80 characters affect how it wraps in Vuepress at smaller screen sizes when serving the docs? The documentation is  in markdown because Vuepress uses markdown. If I change my diff view to side-by-side diff in Gerrit then the text automatically wraps for review and is easily readable.

> Will breaking at 80 characters affect how it wraps in Vuepress at smaller screen sizes when serving the docs?

I haven't used vuepress, but I doubt it has any effect.  Most of the other engines ignore line breaks unless they're multiple lines.

As an aside, why do we use one doc generator for other documentation (ie, github) and another generator specifically for the webui?  That seems at odds a little.

Granted, they're both markdown, so it probably doesn't matter, it's just a little odd, especially when we get the github one for free.

> The documentation is  in markdown because Vuepress uses markdown. If I change my diff view to side-by-side diff in Gerrit then the text automatically wraps for review and is easily readable.

I'm not here to argue the documentation standard.  If you want to change the standard to not require 80 character widths, this code review is not the place to do it.  Feel free to propose a change to the docs directory, which contains the rules for this kind of thing, but I'm going to guess there's a number of vim and command line users that are going to disagree with you.  The reasoning is not _just_ gerrit.

> > Will breaking at 80 characters affect how it wraps in Vuepress at smaller screen sizes when serving the docs?
> I haven't used vuepress, but I doubt it has any effect.  Most of the other engines ignore line breaks unless they're multiple lines.

That is true. The browser will simply treat a line return as a single space.

> As an aside, why do we use one doc generator for other documentation (ie, github) and another generator specifically for the webui?  That seems at odds a little.

> Granted, they're both markdown, so it probably doesn't matter, it's just a little odd, especially when we get the github one for free.

VuePress is free and is using GitHub pages. VuePress is a documentation tool and provides a great deal of formatting to make the documentation easy to consume. I realize that people consume in different ways and feel this solution can meet the needs of everyone. It will be a lower priority issue to resolve across all pages if it is a required change.

I don't know what you mean by "the github one". If you are saying just using markdown in GitHub similar to the docs repo, we felt that the theming and formatting of documentation as browser based documentation was much easier to navigate and share expected patterns.

https://vuepress.vuejs.org/guide/#how-it-works

> > > Will breaking at 80 characters affect how it wraps in Vuepress at smaller screen sizes when serving the docs?
> > I haven't used vuepress, but I doubt it has any effect.  Most of the other engines ignore line breaks unless they're multiple lines.
> 
> That is true. The browser will simply treat a line return as a single space.
> 
> > As an aside, why do we use one doc generator for other documentation (ie, github) and another generator specifically for the webui?  That seems at odds a little.
> 
> > Granted, they're both markdown, so it probably doesn't matter, it's just a little odd, especially when we get the github one for free.
> 
> VuePress is free and is using GitHub pages. VuePress is a documentation tool and provides a great deal of formatting to make the documentation easy to consume. I realize that people consume in different ways and feel this solution can meet the needs of everyone. It will be a lower priority issue to resolve across all pages if it is a required change.

If that's your position, then this argument should really be made to change the current policy to using VuePress everywhere.  Having different "rules" (if you can call them that) in different repos is counter productive to people that need to submit to multiple repos.  For example, if I were submitting here, I would've tested my change in the github UI, and pushed it, without ever realizing that VuePress was used.  Because they're both markdown, maybe it wouldn't have mattered, but the webui shouldn't be inventing its own documentation format disparate from the rest of the project.  That's counterproductive.

> 
> I don't know what you mean by "the github one". If you are saying just using markdown in GitHub similar to the docs repo, we felt that the theming and formatting of documentation as browser based documentation was much easier to navigate and share expected patterns.
> 
> https://vuepress.vuejs.org/guide/#how-it-works

Yes, I mean the existing markdown like the docs and all other source repos use.  If vuepress is really that much better, it should be easy to convince people that it should be used project-wide, not just here.  Barring that, consistency as a project is a good thing and should be prioritized over every repo having their own theming;  If only one repo of the docs are themed, and the rest aren't, it makes for a very messy experience overall.

With that said, you're the maintainer here, so it's up to you.

> > > > Will breaking at 80 characters affect how it wraps in Vuepress at smaller screen sizes when serving the docs?
> > > I haven't used vuepress, but I doubt it has any effect.  Most of the other engines ignore line breaks unless they're multiple lines.
> > 
> > That is true. The browser will simply treat a line return as a single space.
> > 
> > > As an aside, why do we use one doc generator for other documentation (ie, github) and another generator specifically for the webui?  That seems at odds a little.
> > 
> > > Granted, they're both markdown, so it probably doesn't matter, it's just a little odd, especially when we get the github one for free.
> > 
> > VuePress is free and is using GitHub pages. VuePress is a documentation tool and provides a great deal of formatting to make the documentation easy to consume. I realize that people consume in different ways and feel this solution can meet the needs of everyone. It will be a lower priority issue to resolve across all pages if it is a required change.
> 
> If that's your position, then this argument should really be made to change the current policy to using VuePress everywhere.  Having different "rules" (if you can call them that) in different repos is counter productive to people that need to submit to multiple repos.  For example, if I were submitting here, I would've tested my change in the github UI, and pushed it, without ever realizing that VuePress was used.  Because they're both markdown, maybe it wouldn't have mattered, but the webui shouldn't be inventing its own documentation format disparate from the rest of the project.  That's counterproductive.

I can see your point of view from that perspective. Our intent was not to create confusion or introduce counter productivity into the project. We are trying to improve the on-boarding experience. When we joined the project, there weren't any clear client-side development standards for phosphor-webui and it led to lengthy meetings and inconsistency. Our goal was to resolve that problem and make it easy for GUI developers to learn about the project and the patterns without having to rely solely on source code.

We specified in the README that the documentation is created with VuePress, https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue#documentation. We also link to the documentation in the about section of the repo, https://openbmc.github.io/webui-vue/, if you are interested in looking through it.

In addition, we also discussed and demo'd this with the GUI Design Work Group before continuing to invest effort into the documentation using VuePress on 01/08/2020, https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/wiki/GUI-Design-work-group#vue-prototype-discussion.

> > > > > Will breaking at 80 characters affect how it wraps in Vuepress at smaller screen sizes when serving the docs?
> > > > I haven't used vuepress, but I doubt it has any effect.  Most of the other engines ignore line breaks unless they're multiple lines.
> > > 
> > > That is true. The browser will simply treat a line return as a single space.
> > > 
> > > > As an aside, why do we use one doc generator for other documentation (ie, github) and another generator specifically for the webui?  That seems at odds a little.
> > > 
> > > > Granted, they're both markdown, so it probably doesn't matter, it's just a little odd, especially when we get the github one for free.
> > > 
> > > VuePress is free and is using GitHub pages. VuePress is a documentation tool and provides a great deal of formatting to make the documentation easy to consume. I realize that people consume in different ways and feel this solution can meet the needs of everyone. It will be a lower priority issue to resolve across all pages if it is a required change.
> > 
> > If that's your position, then this argument should really be made to change the current policy to using VuePress everywhere.  Having different "rules" (if you can call them that) in different repos is counter productive to people that need to submit to multiple repos.  For example, if I were submitting here, I would've tested my change in the github UI, and pushed it, without ever realizing that VuePress was used.  Because they're both markdown, maybe it wouldn't have mattered, but the webui shouldn't be inventing its own documentation format disparate from the rest of the project.  That's counterproductive.
> 
> I can see your point of view from that perspective. Our intent was not to create confusion or introduce counter productivity into the project. We are trying to improve the on-boarding experience. When we joined the project, there weren't any clear client-side development standards for phosphor-webui and it led to lengthy meetings and inconsistency. Our goal was to resolve that problem and make it easy for GUI developers to learn about the project and the patterns without having to rely solely on source code.
> 
> We specified in the README that the documentation is created with VuePress, https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue#documentation.
> We also link to the documentation in the about section of the repo, https://openbmc.github.io/webui-vue/, if you are interested in looking through it.
> 
> In addition, we also discussed and demo'd this with the GUI Design Work Group before continuing to invest effort into the documentation using VuePress on 01/08/2020, https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/wiki/GUI-Design-work-group#vue-prototype-discussion.


But do you see my point, you're making the on-boarding experience worse by making new people install and understand different tools dependent on where they're at in the codebase?  I'm all for documentation, but one of the big onboarding complaints is that we have no consistency, be it in software or documentation, and it's because when people push a new initiative (like vuepress, or webui-vue) they only do it for the new stuff, or in a portion of the codebase, and everything else gets left behind, and we end up with a worse experience, and no consensus that works for everyone.

It should be noted, when I've gone in the past, the GUI design workgroup routinely contains <5% of the developers on the project, so saying you got consensus on a general documentation style decision in that meeting is kinda hard to assume, and to reiterate, I don't think every sub-project should be inventing its own documentation style or theme, so I wouldn't expect this repo to be deviating from the base style.

I've said my piece, and as I look further, this isn't the patchset that caused this problem, nor does it sounds like there's any desire to change it to the documentation style used everywhere else.  I don't mean to hold up this review because of this.
Whitespace issues.  Please fix all of them.
Sandeepa, I am not sure why the linting is not updating here. We can get together to look at that.
Yes Derick even I noticed this that linting did not update here I had to manually get rid of whitespaces. Yes we can look together at it.

You list a lot of rules above, but you don't list why for any of them.  There's exceptions to every rule, so specifying why something is important, along with examples would be really helpful here.

I've done this kind of thing before, and some of the rules I can see good reasons for, some (like alphabetizing object keys) I'm not really sure what they're there for.  Adding clarity to this section would improve it a lot.
I would be really helpful if you could give one example of exception or something. I'll get a better and clear picture.

Sandeepa, we alphabetize the keys to make them easy to locate. It could be argued that we can also find them by searching. I would like to be consistent, but if other developers start contributing, we will have to enforce that via Gerrit conversation. I am optimistic that this is important since Ed is providing feedback and that others will continue to contribute to the documentation in the future. 

Having the main keys, pageXxxxXxx.xxxXX, seems valuable so that there is some level of organization and every new key is not just added at the end. That is subjective, but is the way we have structured it up to this point.

> Sandeepa, we alphabetize the keys to make them easy to locate. It could be argued that we can also find them by searching. I would like to be consistent, but if other developers start contributing, we will have to enforce that via Gerrit conversation. I am optimistic that this is important since Ed is providing feedback and that others will continue to contribute to the documentation in the future. 

This kind of "why" is exactly what I'm looking for.  Basically, something that takes the form of "we do this because" makes it much clearer why something was done in the past;  That helps with future reviews, because the document becomes self describing, and you only have to link it on failures.

An exception might be the title to the page, because it's in an odd place (the <title> tag), and "OpenBMC" would be the same in every language, maybe it's not worth the effort to call this.  You don't really have to call out exceptions here, but knowing why we do this helps.

> 
> Having the main keys, pageXxxxXxx.xxxXX, seems valuable so that there is some level of organization and every new key is not just added at the end. That is subjective, but is the way we have structured it up to this point.

Can we avoid using company specific things as defaults?

Also, what do the env variables do?  How are they used?  Why would someone wanting internationalization use them?

> Can we avoid using company specific things as defaults?

+1 We aren't actually doing this behind the .env file. However, there is company specific copy out there and we still don't have a clear plan how that will be managed. No one has pushed back or even reviewed outside of IBM. We are trying to collaborate on this and resolve as much as possible to resolve downstream work, but there is a large number of variables to consider. For example, these are just two concerns:

- will everyone be planning to use the translated files that IBM is providing?
- If another company changes the us file, the translation will no longer match

> Also, what do the env variables do?  How are they used?  Why would someone wanting internationalization use them?

No one will internationalize or translate the .env variables. They are used for companies to be able to use a configuration to change the theme, navigation, and routing if they need something the rest of the community does not.

> > Can we avoid using company specific things as defaults?
> 
> +1 We aren't actually doing this behind the .env file. However, there is company specific copy out there and we still don't have a clear plan how that will be managed. No one has pushed back or even reviewed outside of IBM. We are trying to collaborate on this and resolve as much as possible to resolve downstream work, but there is a large number of variables to consider. For example, these are just two concerns:
> 
> - will everyone be planning to use the translated files that IBM is providing?

Personal opinion, OpenBMC should have a base set of translations, and not be company specific.  I would really hope that the same string translated to a different language wouldn't be dependent on which company wrote the change.

If IBM needs specific translations for IBM specific features, I would expect that to go under IBM specific feature flags.

> - If another company changes the us file, the translation will no longer match

Yes.....  This is the advantage of an open source project.  When people add things, it helps everyone, and doesn't need explicit buy in from any company.

> 
> > Also, what do the env variables do?  How are they used?  Why would someone wanting internationalization use them?
> 
> No one will internationalize or translate the .env variables. They are used for companies to be able to use a configuration to change the theme, navigation, and routing if they need something the rest of the community does not.

If they're not used for internationalization.... why are they mentioned in the internationalization document?  Based on the above, maybe this line can be completely removed?

> > > Can we avoid using company specific things as defaults?
> > 
> > +1 We aren't actually doing this behind the .env file. However, there is company specific copy out there and we still don't have a clear plan how that will be managed. No one has pushed back or even reviewed outside of IBM. We are trying to collaborate on this and resolve as much as possible to resolve downstream work, but there is a large number of variables to consider. For example, these are just two concerns:
> > 
> > - will everyone be planning to use the translated files that IBM is providing?
> 
> Personal opinion, OpenBMC should have a base set of translations, and not be company specific.  I would really hope that the same string translated to a different language wouldn't be dependent on which company wrote the change.
> 
> If IBM needs specific translations for IBM specific features, I would expect that to go under IBM specific feature flags.

It all depends on the translator regarding to how a string is translated. We do have a standard we follow when it comes to language and so far the community has agreed to the content that IBM has contributed. However, I do know that Factory Reset has some language that is IBM specific and no one has objected to that page moving forward. I am not sure how we are going to support some of these cases that are inevitably going to surface.


> > - If another company changes the us file, the translation will no longer match
> 
> Yes.....  This is the advantage of an open source project.  When people add things, it helps everyone, and doesn't need explicit buy in from any company.

This leads me to believe that the contributor that changes the language needs to be responsible for providing the translation for all supported languages impacted by their change? I am not sure what to do about the translation files. Maybe each company translates on their own and translated files remain downstream only. IBM will send the English file for translation after code freeze before a release. The moment anything is changed in the English file the all the translated files are out of sync. Have any thoughts on that?
 

> > > Also, what do the env variables do?  How are they used?  Why would someone wanting internationalization use them?
> > 
> > No one will internationalize or translate the .env variables. They are used for companies to be able to use a configuration to change the theme, navigation, and routing if they need something the rest of the community does not.
> 
> If they're not used for internationalization.... why are they mentioned in the internationalization document?  Based on the above, maybe this line can be completely removed?

Yes, we can remove that line. It is not related to i18n. Sandeepa already said she would remove it.

> > > > Can we avoid using company specific things as defaults?
> > > 
> > > +1 We aren't actually doing this behind the .env file. However, there is company specific copy out there and we still don't have a clear plan how that will be managed. No one has pushed back or even reviewed outside of IBM. We are trying to collaborate on this and resolve as much as possible to resolve downstream work, but there is a large number of variables to consider. For example, these are just two concerns:
> > > 
> > > - will everyone be planning to use the translated files that IBM is providing?
> > 
> > Personal opinion, OpenBMC should have a base set of translations, and not be company specific.  I would really hope that the same string translated to a different language wouldn't be dependent on which company wrote the change.
> > 
> > If IBM needs specific translations for IBM specific features, I would expect that to go under IBM specific feature flags.
> 
> It all depends on the translator regarding to how a string is translated. We do have a standard we follow when it comes to language and so far the community has agreed to the content that IBM has contributed. However, I do know that Factory Reset has some language that is IBM specific and no one has objected to that page moving forward. I am not sure how we are going to support some of these cases that are inevitably going to surface.

Sounds like a future design doc, but "I need something specific and non-standard for my company" I think should be separated from "I need multi language support".  The default should be to find consensus in openbmc where we can.

> 
> 
> > > - If another company changes the us file, the translation will no longer match
> > 
> > Yes.....  This is the advantage of an open source project.  When people add things, it helps everyone, and doesn't need explicit buy in from any company.
> 
> This leads me to believe that the contributor that changes the language needs to be responsible for providing the translation for all supported languages impacted by their change?

No, I would expect only the languages they care about.  I'm not the maintainer here, but expecting every submitter to know every language seems a big constraining.  I would expect the submitter to make the accommodations for the default language (I'm assuming english) to prove that the code works, then those that care about the other languages can add the appropriate support.  Although, again, I'm not the maintainer here.

> I am not sure what to do about the translation files. Maybe each company translates on their own and translated files remain downstream only.

This seems like a kinda odd policy, and at odds with collaboration.  In open source, I don't really want to speculate on your "downstream" that's your business, and has no bearing on what we do here.  For those that need the translations, upstream the various languages, and make sure there are reasonable fallbacks in place in code.  If the community thinks a language should be supported, it'll get a config file, if the community doesn't care, it will be incomplete.  If a language is incomplete to the point where it's not useful, it will be removed.

> IBM will send the English file for translation after code freeze before a release. The moment anything is changed in the English file the all the translated files are out of sync. Have any thoughts on that?

I see two paths here:

1. Before allowing a new language in, make sure specific maintainers are assigned for each language in question, and set the expectation that they'll provide translations for new strings within X months of being checked into master, and ahead of releases.  If no maintainer presents themselves willing to do that, I would expect the new language to be barred from master.  FWIW, when we check in multiple languages of message registry into Redfish (as is allowed in the standard), this option will be my preference, where I am the maintainer.

2. Alternatively, maintain feature flags for every conceivable option, and have cross reference checks between the required strings and the option itself, and only allow a language to be enabled if it's complete.  This seems hard to do given the level of detail you would need, but could also get you a result if you don't want to assign language maintainers.

I personally think the first option is better, and more open source friendly, as anyone can upstream new definitions, and the code works as well as people care to make it.  It also conveys ownership to people, which I think is helpful.

>  
> 
> > > > Also, what do the env variables do?  How are they used?  Why would someone wanting internationalization use them?
> > > 
> > > No one will internationalize or translate the .env variables. They are used for companies to be able to use a configuration to change the theme, navigation, and routing if they need something the rest of the community does not.
> > 
> > If they're not used for internationalization.... why are they mentioned in the internationalization document?  Based on the above, maybe this line can be completely removed?
> 
> Yes, we can remove that line. It is not related to i18n. Sandeepa already said she would remove it.

I missed that the first time around.  Understood.
You're writing documentation here, this statement feels like it's better suited to a commit message, as it's laying out exactly what a commit will do.
The below code snippets are examples of this.
Ah, that's my fault, it wasn't clear to me that the below example had plurals in it, but indeed it does.

nit: not really an issue with these docs.

Should we just wrap msgBoxConfirm in our own API that takes the dictionary key variables directly instead of having to constantly call this.$tc by hand?  That seems a lot easier to get right, rather than having every user call their own instance of this.$tc 4 times per modal.

It would be a little more than wrapping the method provided by Bootstrap-vue. We would need to create our own modal component that wrapped the Bootsrap-vue component. We did something similar with Alerts. It is possible, we could extend this with a mixin. Thanks for the idea Ed.

Change to:
, so they can be easily replaced.

Remove essentially and just say:

The OpenBMC Web UI...
Was thinking the same, thanks for bringing this up.

Actually as I mentioned 'parts' initially in the sentence that is why I wrote 'those parts' in the second part of the sentence. Either ways I'll change it to 'so they can be easily replaced' which seems to fit better here.

Can you add a space between the keys. and It?

In general, can you look through this whole block and add a space after periods to separate sentences?
Yes I'll add spaces after full stops and commas for better readability.

Formatting:
- Update alignment
- Use JS instead of Vue

```JS
"pageDumps": {
  "dumpsAvailableOnBmc": "Dumps available on BMC"
}
```

Took reference from other documents and there Vue was used. It would be really helpful if you could maybe let me know why use js instead of Vue. As shown in the screenshot you shared is it because it looks better formatted on screen with JS than with Vue?
I provided a screen shot in the main reply thead that showed the formatting difference on the static generated files.

Formatting:
- Update alignment
- Use JS instead of Vue

```JS
"modal": {
  "deleteDump": "Delete dump | Delete dumps"
```

Actually, thank you for the push back! The formatting is better if you use json instead of Vue or js. This is also true for the example at line 20. The reason is that is that the language file is a json file and the formatting in the docs is better. Other wise, the text is one color (green using JS or white using Vue)

Formatting example using:
- json for lines 20 and 30
- Vue for line 25
- JS for line 35

    okTitle: this.$tc('pageDumps.modal.deleteDump'),
    cancelTitle: this.$t('global.action.cancel'),
  })
Seems like more than one space? 😊

Sorry...use json instead and in terimal run the following:

`run npm docs:serve`
Sorry, can you use json instead. 😐

Glad we are writing documentation like this! 

Can you add a bit more here..

Why should this merge into webui-vue, i.e. how does it help webui-vue?

I'm sorry, one more edit please. :) 
Can we change this to Add?
Also, we don't need the period at the end of the title. 

The commit message should read like a sentence...

When this patchest is merged it will "Add internationalization documentation"

`page`
